captions.text: [CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: Come to Weissach
at the Porsche Museum and
drive our Le Mans-winning 962.
Are you serious?
I said.
The 1987 car?
Rothmans livery?

The machine I thought I'd never
see in the raw, let

alone sit in, let alone
drive the track on
which it was developed?
That's right, they said.

And you can meet the legend that
is Norbert Singer, the

man who designed the car, the
man involved in every Porsche
Le Mans victory since the 917.
I'm there, I said.
Why is the 962 so special?

Why is this series of cars,
956 and 962, why
were they so dominant?

And why even now do I look at
this car with the Rothmans

livery and think it's the
coolest car ever?

NORBERT SINGER: I
think this was--

in that area, it was the first
car with real ground effects.

Of course, other cars also had
some ground effects, but not

really made for doing
faster lap times.

And we were, let's say, lucky,
or we found the right key to
do quite a big step.

And in comparison, when we
talked about downforce, the

amount of downforce, our aim
was the 917/30, the Can-Am

car, which didn't
care about drag.

It would just get downforce,
because it had 1,000
horsepower.
There was enough power there.

And we knew how much downforce
we had then.

When we saw that we can even
double that downforce or make

it 2 and 1/2 times more
downforce, then we knew that

this is the right way, with a
reasonable track, of course.
CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah.

And this was your discovery of
the ground effect technology.

Obviously, you were doing things
that not even Formula

One was doing, because they
didn't have as much body to
work with, did they?

NORBERT SINGER: Yeah, Formula
One did ground effects two or
three years earlier.
CHRIS HARRIS: With the skirts?

NORBERT SINGER: With
the skirts, yeah.
And that's where we started.

Because we saw that
for Formula One
it's working perfectly.

The lap times were
much faster.

So we started like
Formula One.

We copied a kind of Formula
One with a wider cockpit,

because there was a
two-seater car.

And it turned out that it
does not work at all.
There was no way.

And even when we put its skirts
on-- which regulation
doesn't allow--

just to learn ground effects,
it doesn't work.
It was even worse with skirts.

And then we realized we need
the air going from the side

through the tunnels,
which is for the
sports car most important.

And then we modified that area
to help that area to improve
the downforce.

And this was the key
to everything.

CHRIS HARRIS: The ground effect
gave this incredible

performance, but if the car was
known for speed, it was

also known for this durability,
this reliability.

And there were so many stories
of customers coming to buy the

cars, buying the car, sign the
documents, give him the key,

turn the key, start the
car, and just go.
It's really the truth?
NORBERT SINGER: Yeah, yeah.

Because, well, reliability was
always a big story in Porsche,

because Porsche was always
thinking with every race car

or nearly every race car,
thinking about Le Mans.

And Le Mans means not
just top speed.
It means also durability.
You had to run first 24 hours.

And then you can see
where you are.
Maybe you win.

And durability was
a big thing.

And this was, let's say, the
education in Porsche.

Everybody was thinking,
in whatever you do,
does it last 24 hours?

And this was not just
on the 956.

It was all the previous
types as well.

CHRIS HARRIS: What was the most
difficult component to
make last 24 hours?

NORBERT SINGER: It's
the gearbox.
CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah?
And the synchromesh.
NORBERT SINGER: Right.

Of course, we had a lot
of experience in that.

So it was not the problem
on this car, the 956.
But on the previous cars.
CHRIS HARRIS: 926.

NORBERT SINGER: Yeah, we had
problems with gearboxes.

Because Le Mans with the long
straight, there were no

chicanes in, you run a minute,
or even longer on full

throttle and one gear,
in the top gear.

And this very often hurts
the top gear.

First, the engine, but when the
engine was reliable, then
the next is the gears.

CHRIS HARRIS: And did it feel
like a challenge every time
you went to Le Mans.

NORBERT SINGER: Yeah,
Le Mans was always
a challenge, whenever.
Even if you have a--

let's say, a reliable car, you
are never 100% sure that some
details may go wrong.

Which went two times or three
times you were right, but the

third or fourth times,
they can fail.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
CHRIS HARRIS: Oh yes.

So this is the Porsche 962,
which won Le Mans in 1987.

It was driven by Al Holbert,
HJ Stuck, and Derek Bell.

I'm at Weissach, Porsche's
test track in
them Swabian hills.

I don't really know how to
describe what this is in--
yes, in comparative terms.

Let me try for a second as
we just turn this key.

This red Porsche key which
particularly comes from a

series production car
from that era.

Because it's a car that won Le
Mans that starts on a key.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: Sounds a bit like
a motorbike at low speed.

Well, let me try and think of
witty things to compare this
experience to.
Let's go and drive it.

Throttle pedal's heavy,
clutch is heavy.

First is a door blade
back towards you.

This is Le Mans era,
Le Mans gearing.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: Car wants to
change direction, doesn't have
that much aero.

We'll leave it in third
through here.
Also it happens that--
[ROARING ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: --when that
turbo motor comes good.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]
CHRIS HARRIS: There she goes.
Ho, ho, ho!
God knows how fast it's going.

It's really potent, right from
the aero, let's say.

Second gear to this
right-hander then.

I'm going to try and change
the throttle a bit.
The gearing's long.

This thing will do 240
miles an hour.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: This right-hander
carries the

speed, and it's looks
like I'm going over.

This is pretty much
bumpy there.

The torque is what
you think of.
The motor is just fantastic.
And the noises.
850 kilograms.

850 kilograms, about
650 horsepower.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: And, of course, it
was all about going fast in
a straight line, really.

Get it round the corners, fast,
in a straight line.

But it really has
lovely steering.
It's pretty neutral.

And then it just goes
on the straights.

The torque of the motor is
great, and then you get this
wallop at the top end.
Yeah, it's moving here.
And it's physical, too.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: It's hard to know
where to start with just
how special this car is.

The bodywork is still battered
from the race, the interior
beautifully tatty.

It has more power than a Noble
M600, and yet it weighs 400
kilograms less.

The acceleration
is relentless.

Driving it is the best thing
I've done in years.

And driving the car today, first
of all, I'm speechless
at how fast it is.

How easy the car is to
drive in real terms.

One observation, the car has a
spool differential, but it

doesn't understeer it,
really, at low speed.
How do you do that?
Because it should just push.

Particularly with the turbo
motor it should just,
tuh-tuh-tuh.
But it doesn't.

NORBERT SINGER: Well, it's a
long way to find the setup to

get rid of these understeering
It still has some
understeering.

In fact, it depends on the
tires you're using.
But it's--

and we made several kinds
of comparisons with a

differential, a lock
differential.

And it always turned out this
is the fastest way, doing it

with the spool on that car with
these tires at that time.
Today, I think, a spool is--

you can do it with a
differential because you have

learned a lot now with the
differentials, with these
different things.

And now a differential
is a must.

But in those days, just
spool, was the best.

CHRIS HARRIS: On the long-tail
car, the 1987 car, obviously

ground effect, long-tail for Le
Mans, but a big gurney on
the back, a really big gurney.
Why was this?
For stability or because that'

NORBERT SINGER: It's for
stability, and it helps the
front axle.

CHRIS HARRIS: Helps
the front axle?
How did you work that out?

NORBERT SINGER: No, this is
funny, because when you work--

when the ground effects is
really working, when you do

something on the rear end, it's
very often you have a

response from the
front, a bigger
response from the front.

And then you know your ground
effects is working.
Because they're on the floor.

You influence them, and
the other way round.

If you do something on
the floor, it has
influence on the back.
So this is an amazing thing.

CHRIS HARRIS: But clearly your
knowledge of the way air

flowing over something makes
that behavior is
extraordinary.

Because you went ahead and
just-- this was all
experimentation, wasn't it?
NORBERT SINGER: Yeah.

CHRIS HARRIS: And do you think
motorsport now is--

that you can't make that
big game now, can you?
Everything's incremental.
NORBERT SINGER: Right.

CHRIS HARRIS: Does that
excite you less?

NORBERT SINGER: We were
at the beginning.
There you could do big steps.

Now the big steps are done, and
you have to find all the
parts and pieces together.

At the end, it's a
similar big step.

CHRIS HARRIS: Is there another
museum that allows you to do

150 miles an hour for lap after
lap in its multimillion
dollar exhibits?

And is there a cooler man
that Norbert Singer?

The man who created this
dominant machine, and yet who

is now retired and teaches at a
university because he wants

to share his knowledge with
the next generation.
What a car, what a bloke.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

title: Flat Out In a Le Mans Winning Porsche 962 - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: Brightblue Orange

comments.text:
I'm no super-expert, but I think there are many differences that makes an 
F1 car more difficult to handle, but there are two main reasons: First of 
all, power to weight-ratio, and second, aerodynamics. The F1 car has a 
power to weight-ratio that is grater than 1. That is absolutely enormous. 
And the F1 car, especially the ones from the period, have aerodynamics that 
produces downforce, and grip, at higher speeds. This means a F1-car does 
not have the grip you need, until you drive it really fast. Have you seen 
the video of Richard Hammond trying to drive the Renault F1? It pretty much 
sums it up right there. Also, I've had the opportunity to drive a F1-car 
myself. Takuma Sato's car from 2002 to be precise. It was a gift on my 30th 
birthday from all my friends. And I can tell you, trying to handle a car 
like that is like trying to handle a rollercoaster... :) Oh, and by the 
way, nobody on youtube ever believe me when I say I've driven a F1-car, so 
check out this:

rajamakiracing.com

If you get the chance to do something like this...take it.

comments.author: Weirdnamed

comments.text:
you're basing this equation on what exactly? straight line downforce is 
exactly that, a straight line of air going over the car hitting points 
which causes downforce at certain speeds. the airflow is interrupted during 
a turn and the tires loose grip also. in theory if you had tires that could 
stick to the pavement and never loose grip regardless of how fast you're 
going then your idea would work, just remember there are many parts to 
downforce and G force beyond aerodynamics, that's why most racers will tell 
you torque, downforce and handling is important but it's the tires that 
decide weather you win or loose. mechanical grip while in a turn is what 
makes high G turns possible not so much downforce, or maybe I should say 
mechanical grip is more important than the downforce. either way you're a 
smart guy you get my point.
comments.author: Loki

comments.text: +BlackSkySora Maybe it would be possible in oval circuits.
comments.author: SalveMonesvol

comments.author: BlackSkySora

comments.text:
+Tim Kunert No, according to what I said, they can experience more g-force. 
Generally, the centripetal force that can be created with help from 
aerodynamics grows slower than the momentum preventing the car to change 
direction, therefore the turning radius also increases. 
 And don't try to give me a physics lesson, if you want to find any errors, 
you might find some misuse of language, since I'm not a native speaker.
comments.author: SalveMonesvol

comments.author: Marijn Kramer

comments.text:
So, was he downshifting through all the gears individually because it's 
required of the car, or was this car built when the braking systems were 
still less than optimal for such massive speed and still required gear 
braking?﻿
comments.author: Jake Bopp

comments.text:
The car's brakes are more then adequate. "Gear Braking" AKA engine braking 
is bad for manual transmissions whether it be a race car or a street car. 
Forcing the engine speed to slow down the car by downshifting alone puts 
tremendous strain on the gear box not to mention the forced difference of 
the new drive line input speed to current tire rotation speed will upset 
the car on track. Chris is using the heel toe technique going into a 
corner. The brakes are first used to slow the car down then the downshift 
is made & whilst the clutch is disengaged (pedal down) he blips the 
throttle to rev-match the engine to the transmission then lets up on the 
clutch pedal. This is all done very quickly & does not upset the car nor 
puts strain on the gear box. The technique has been used for decades prior 
to even the 962 being built.
comments.author: Kronaphasia

comments.text:
As chris stated in the video the car has very long gears for Le mans. With 
that said a (for example) 5th to 3rd downshift would be too great of a gear 
down to do all at once, most likely will over rev the motor. 5th to 4th is 
much more conservative and is still probably close to a 5th to 3rd in your 
normally geared street car. 

Think about a corvette. It does 60mph in 1st gear and tops out at 200mph. 
In comparison the porsche does 240mph. you do the math.
comments.author: John Ryan Lewis

comments.text:
Well, until today, gear braking is "mandatory" on racing, independently of 
the braking power of the car, because it makes braking and corner exit 
faster. It doesn't matter if it's a semi-automatic or H gearbox, the only 
difference on H gearboxes is that you need to apply the "heel and toe" 
technique when downshifting (as you can see in this video). I'm not an 
expert, so I could be wrong about some things.
comments.author: Maxi Díaz

comments.text:

i watched a 962 vs LMP2 RS Spyder at Laguna Seca.  the Spyder was faster, 
and a generation old now.

comments.text:
We have a 962 at work and I can attest to how amazing these cars are. I 
really wish this video could have delved deeper into the intricacies and 
engineering that are in these cars. One thing this video cannot relay is 
how the car feels when it is running; there is a raw, visceral feeling of 
the exhaust pulses hitting your body, and the smells are amazing.﻿

comments.author: FullThrottleLegal

comments.text:
Does it possibly get any better than this? Porsche invites you to 
the Valhalla of Weissach and give you the keys to a historic 962 to play 
with.  Talking with the motorsport genius of Norbert Singer has to be an 
absolute rush.
I was in awe the first time I saw a 962 up close at Mid-Ohio in 1984 or so. 
The Lowenbrau 962 of Holbert and Bob Akin's Coke car parked beside of it. 
The Group 44 Jag was on the other side of Holbert's 962.

comments.text:

withstand 24h races... amazing engineering!﻿
